repnme.cdata!:
India - Second Karnataka Economic
            Restructuring Loan /Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, with satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. The experience
            of both Economic Restructuring operations in Karnataka,
            supports the conclusion that a series of single-tranche
            adjustment operations, anchored through a medium-term reform
            framework at the state-level, can be an effective instrument
            to support reforms in India, through a demonstration effect.
            It is suggested that smaller loans/credits foster
            effectiveness, adding impetus to the reform program. Lessons
            include the following. 1) undoubtedly, having a consolidated
            fiscal target forced the government to look beyond the
            budget, and introduce fiscal discipline into the power
            sector. The falling financial losses of the sector bear
            testimony to the success of this approach, and, clear
            milestones for power sector reform also helped monitor
            progress in this very difficult reform area. 2) Fiscal
            targeting with respect to the budget needs to allow for
            volatile growth given the dependence of states on
            agriculture, and the dependence of agriculture on an
            uncertain rainfall. Thus, nominal (Rupee) targets should be
            adhered to wherever possible, at least until the fiscal
            position is consolidated. Other lessons reinforce the notion
            that institutional reforms take time, and difficult reforms
            require cooperation across departments, such as the
            industrial deregulation, which required the input from
            departments as diverse as Environment, Labor and the
            Inspectorate of Factories.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Second Karnataka Economic
            Restrucuturing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Karnataka Economic
            Restructuring Project includes: 1) reforms in fiscal policy,
            and public expenditure management; 2) administrative
            reforms; 3) reforms to promote private sector development;
            and, 4) strengthening of poverty monitoring, and statistical
            capacity. These comprehensive reforms will benefit the
            restoration of the state's financial health, governance
            and services delivery, and will help in achieving higher
            levels of private investments, and higher economic growth,
            in reducing poverty, and in improving social indicators.
            Nonetheless, risks remain over a potential slippage in the
            fiscal framework due to the global, and India's
            slowdown, and implementation delays of key sectoral reforms,
            particularly in the power sector. Further risks include the
            resistance to institutional, and governance reforms;
            however, such risks have been contained to date.

docna.cdata!:
India - Second Karnataka Economic
            Restrucuturing Project
